articles.title: AI vs. Machine Learning vs. Deep Learning (without the marketing fluff)
articles.author: Samuel Stefan
articles.content:
People throw “AI”, “machine learning”, and “deep learning” around like they mean the same thing. They don’t.

AI

Artificial Intelligence is the umbrella: any system that performs tasks that normally require human intelligence.

Machine Learning

ML learns patterns from data (linear regression, trees, forests).

Deep Learning

DL is ML with multi-layer neural networks, great for text/images/audio.

Quick rule

  • Rules: AI (not ML).
  • Learned from data: ML (maybe DL).
  • Multi-layer nets: DL.

articles.title: How neural networks actually learn (a practical mental model)
articles.author: Samuel Stefan
articles.content:
Neural networks don’t “understand” data. They optimize weights to reduce a loss.

  1. Forward pass
  2. Loss
  3. Backprop gradients
  4. Gradient descent updates

Failures are usually bad data, bad optimization, or wrong objective.

articles.title: Overfitting explained with one brutal example
articles.author: Samuel Stefan
articles.content:
Overfitting = great on training, bad on new data.

Example: memorizing “Street A houses cost 200k” fails on “Street B”.

Fix with more data, regularization, simpler models, early stopping, and proper validation.

articles.title: Train/test splits: why 80/20 isn’t a magic spell
articles.author: Samuel Stefan
articles.content:
80/20 isn’t a law. Use cross-validation for small datasets, chronological splits for time series, stratification for imbalance.

What matters: no leakage and realistic evaluation.

articles.title: Data leakage: the silent killer of ML projects
articles.author: Samuel Stefan
articles.content:
Leakage happens when training sees info not available at prediction time.

  • Fit scalers on full data
  • Target-derived features
  • Duplicates across splits
  • Shuffled time series

Split first. Preprocess second. Use pipelines.

articles.title: Prompt engineering that isn’t cringe: 5 patterns that work
articles.author: Samuel Stefan
articles.content: Useful patterns: constraints, examples, plan-then-execute, forced checks, and splitting tasks into steps.

articles.title: RAG in plain language: how to reduce hallucinations (sometimes)
articles.author: Samuel Stefan
articles.content:
RAG = retrieve relevant docs first, then generate grounded in them.

Good retrieval beats fancy prompting. Measure it.

articles.title: Why AI models fail in production (and it’s not the model)
articles.author: Samuel Stefan
articles.content: Production failures are usually drift, skew, latency, missing monitoring, or workflow mismatch.

articles.title: A checklist for writing technical articles people actually read
articles.author: Samuel Stefan
articles.content:
• Start with the problem
  • Short paragraphs
  • Headings often
  • Examples early
  • End with next steps

articles.title: Search and filters UX: what users expect (and what breaks trust)
articles.author: Samuel Stefan
articles.content: Search must be predictable: title/author/content, URL-persisted filters, clear empty-state + reset.

articles.title: SEO for SPAs: what you can do without a backend
articles.author: Samuel Stefan
articles.content: Set title + description per route, OpenGraph tags, canonical URLs, and JSON-LD for articles. SSR/prerender is best but not required for basics.

articles.title: Reliability engineering for student projects: design for failure
articles.author: Samuel Stefan
articles.content: Use a provider chain: cache → primary API → backup → local seed. Show an offline banner so users trust the system.
